questions.question_text: Which of the following is the template for the grub.cfg file?

discussion.content:
Correction Answer: A. /etc/default/grub

grub.cfg is generated automatically from the content of the /etc/default/grub file and the /etc/grub.d directory. You should modify or add to those files to configure GRUB 2. After making changes, you must explicitly rebuild the grub.cfg file by typing the update-grub command.
The /etc/default directory contains configuration files for a few programs such as Google Chrome, useradd, and grub.

A is the right option.
https://opensource.com/article/17/3/introduction-grub2-configuration-linux

questions.question_text: A Linux administrator built a GitLab server. Later that day, a software engineer tried to access the server to upload the repository during the final step of installation. The software engineer could not access the website. Which of the following firewall rules would allow access to this site?

discussion.content:
Actually, the BEST answer is A.
The key in the question is that it is the software engineer's FIRST time accessing the server, therefore we must specify NEW connections. I agree that the first rule should be RELATED and ESTABLISHED, but this doesn't allow NEW connections. Only A includes the NEW keyword and would "allow access to this site", and therefore, the BEST answer is A. Question does not ask for best optimization of iptable firewalls.

Allowing Established and Related Incoming Connections

As network traffic generally needs to be two-way – incoming and outgoing – to work properly, it is typical to create a firewall rule that allows established and related incoming traffic, so that the server will allow return traffic for outgoing connections initiated by the server itself. This command will allow that:

 sudo iptables -A INPUT -m conntrack --ctstate ESTABLISHED,RELATED -j ACCEPT

https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/iptables-essentials-common-firewall-rules-and-commands

Again, I question both the relevancy of these questions to the current XK0-004 Exam content. Hasn't filewalld all but replaced iptables everywhere except in legacy environments? The correct answer is "C".
